ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about how to write a strong personal essay. I also learned how to give and receive criticism effectively.
Writing essays and analyzing essays from the perspective of craft elements.
The course taught me various creative writing approaches and exposed me to many interesting texts.

Knowledge into how to write various creative non-fiction essays. Insights into those techniques, from leads to passive voice to figurative language. My writing skills seriously developed with this class.
I learned a lot about how to write essays in non-academic contexts as well as to how to read a variety of articles and interpret the techniques employed by the authors.
Good tips for writing non-fiction essays.
I feel like I became a much better writer, focusing on the craft of my writing and modeling good writing we saw in class.

My writing skills improved significantly. I learned about many different types of nonfiction writing, and read some incredible pieces that I probably wouldn't have read otherwise on a wide variety of subjects.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The readings were varied and interesting, the essay workshopping was productive, and the feedback was useful.

Weaknesses: none

This course is very well-organized: I know what I need to do every week and every class. There's a strong sense of participation in and out of the classroom. The materials are not challenging to read and the workload is also approachable.

The course was amazing. Professor Saraceni is a great mentor and every seminar was interesting and memorable in its own way. The discussions were great and the feedback on essays was really helpful. No weaknesses!

One of the best courses at Yale, super well organized and interesting. The readings are diverse and not too long, so it engages all the students. Classes are formatted in discussion and with good classmates this definitely turns your twice-a-week english seminar into lively sessions that you look forward to. Prof. Saraceni is also creative with the class assignments, from free-writes to small group presentations on a particular reading. The essays being graded on second draft is by far the best aspect of this class; it means that you really get a chance to improve your work and grow as a writer without the pressure of doing super well on the first go. Loved the workshop format too.
Strengths: Professor Saraceni is amazing, readings were very interesting, and essays were fairly spaced. I don't think this course has any weaknesses.
Great class! The essays they pick to read are really great, and you get good feedback on the essays you write yourself.
Honestly, I have no suggestions for improvement, I really enjoyed this course.

The revisions and workshops process was the biggest strength. I would've liked to write another essay, though, about a place. I know that this essay was removed to lighten the workload, but I think it would have been manageable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. You will read a lot of great essays from great authors, and learn what techniques they use that you can emulate. Peer-led workshops helped to improve writing, and I honestly think I improved as a writer because of this course.

I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to learn writing creative essays. It covers a wide range of topics (personal, place, portrait, argumentative, humor) and the reading materials are very intriguing and diverse.
Absolutely! There is a lot for everyone to learn and enjoy.

Absolutely; its one of those courses that Yale just does so well at. All the professors (although Prof. Saraceni in particular) are incredible. All the readings have something interesting for you to learn. All class discussions are a resource for your development. All the assignments push you as a writer. Take it take it take it.

Absolutely! Whether you are very experienced or have no experience with writing, you will learn a lot of valuable skills in this course while not sacrificing time for other courses. Workload is manageable. Prof Saraceni is great. Overall, one of the best courses I have taken here at Yale!
yes! loved the readings and my prof
Yep! It's a classic class, really good for improving writing, and Saraceni is a great professor!
Yes, it was an interesting and enjoyable class, I feel like the stories we read were mostly interesting and helped improve my writing, but it wasn't an intense class and there wasn't too much work.

Absolutely. The structure of the course allowed me to explore various forms of nonfiction prose that I wouldn't have been able to explore otherwise. The multiple revisions and workshops greatly improved both my writing and my ability to assess other's writing and my own.
